Reviews.Content: Pleasant stay in Old Style Asakusa I really enjoyed our stay in Asakusa. It was a bit like staying in the suburbs rather than Any City Japan. The metro was a 10 min walk (2 stations in different locations) but the Tsukuba Express is 2 mins away and links to Akihabara. The entertainment area is across the road but does not intrude or make one feel unsafe. The restaurants in the area all seemed to stay open quite late which was welcome. Our room was huge and had a great view of the temple and fair ground. I feel sorry for the previous reviewer because we had no problem with noise, air conditioning or uncleanliness. We had a drink in the bar which was fine but expensive and smoky - this seemed to be the norm for all hotel bars. Breakfast was reasonable with some excellent fresh apple juice. I would recommend.
Reviews.Author: Blackcat2

Reviews.Content: Save yourselves from this wretched hotel!!! Me and my husband booked this hotel for Hotelclub website for 4 nights for 180$ a night not including breakfast. This was the second most expensive hotel in Japan (out of 5 hotels in 3 weeks) but by far the worst. There were hairs in the sink, on the bed, in the tub, something smeared in the toilet, dust and tangled electric wires by the bed. The worst thing was the screeching loud noises made from the in-wall piping - we couldn't get sleep. The air conditioning didn't work (apparently there were two switches in two different places in the room. How are we supposed to know?) Plus it was a smoking room, although we asked for a non smoking one (so it stank too). They could only transfer us to a twin room so we left , paying a fine of 180$ and spending half a day on moving to a different hotel. It was a nightmare. BTW - crappy location - whore houses, noise, no train close to the hotel (- there's only this one temple in walking distance. All in all - save your selves from this wretched place!!!
Reviews.Author: Meirav1981

Reviews.Content: Wonderful service, great view, nice room I knew I wanted to stay in this area of Tokyo, because of proximity to the Asakusa Kannon Temple, the old style Japanese feeling of the area and the shopping area at the temple. This hotel exceeded expectations because the room was much larger than expected. There was a sitting area and a floor to ceiling window. The western style bathroom was large for a Japanese hotel room and had a bidette. The bed was hard, but comfortable. There was a cigarette odor when we entered (there are no 'no smoking' rooms) but the bell girl immediately brought a deoderizing spray that (amazingly) worked. Just one example of the very accomodating staff.The halls were wide and well appointed--nice carpeting and wallpaper.The check-in staff was outstanding. They wrote out directions to attractions, helped with pronounciation, spoke good English, helped with learning some Japanese, even walked outside to show the direction if we appeared bewildered.We did not eat at the restaurant. It was too expensive for us, but the food looked good and it was full most of the time we were there.The hotel does accept tours, but it is difficult for buses to get into the turn. The hotel appeared to be very popular for weddings; we saw at least three separate events during our three day stay. Although the hotel was nearly full, it was very quiet. There were a lot of families with children, couples, seniors.
Reviews.Author: princessLA

Reviews.Content: Luxury Hotel in Akasaka * A luxury hotel in quite a down-to-earth area鈥?Staff are very helpful and welcoming鈥?Decor is opulent yet slightly old-fashioned鈥?Double room was huge with a fantastic view鈥?Japanese restaurants inside were very tasty and a great experience
Reviews.Author: innit76

Reviews.Content: Overnight Narita to Asakusa We needed to stay overnight between flights arriving and departing Narita. Deciding to avoid airport hotels, we chose the Asakusa View as being reasonably accessible from Narita (take the Skyliner to Ueno and a short taxi ride). We arrived at about 4.00 pm and departed at 7.30 the following morning. The hotel itself was adequate for a short stay, although the carpets were a bit grubby and the room was very basic. The staff were very helpful. However, the real plus was the short walk from the hotel to the temple, pagoda and wonderful pedestrian streets lined with shops and restaurants - a memorable evening before returning to Narita. We are so glad we made this side trip intead of staying at a Narita airport hotel!
Reviews.Author: Brockles

Reviews.Content: Friendly high-rise on the dooorstep of the Senso-ji temple My partner and I stayed here for 6 nights in October. We arrived at the Asakusa View Hotel after 16 hours travelling and were delighted to find it even better than described in the other reviews here. As you come in through the door 鈥?helped by uniformed porters and doormen 鈥?the Mimosa caf茅 is directly in front of you. Our room wasn鈥檛 ready when we arrived (around 12:00) so we enjoyed a relaxing coffee there before going up to the room on the 20th floor. There are 6 good-sized quick lifts and we never needed to wait long for one to arrive. To the left of the caf茅 (which is fronted by a French-themed patisserie counter 鈥?you have to try the green cake for a real fusion of French and Japanese tastes!) is the small hotel shop and a couple of internet terminals. Immediately to the right of the caf茅 don鈥檛 miss the portable shrine. Further to the right of the lobby are the Reception and Information desks. Throughout our 6-day stay we enjoyed friendly and courteous service from all the hotel staff.We weren鈥檛 on the recommended west side of the hotel but still enjoyed good views eastwards across to Shinjuku through the floor-to-ceiling bay window. Look out for the giant 鈥楳aneki Neko鈥?(waving cat) sculpture on one of the nearby buildings. The room was a smoking room (the hotel isn鈥檛 100% non-smoking by any means) and good size by any standards, with a queen size bed. Wardrobe space was a little tight but there鈥檚 a chest of drawers too and plenty of floor space for cases. In addition there鈥檚 a narrow console table, a desk, and a small table with 2 armchairs in the window bay. The bathroom was fine, not palatial but no smaller than in most London hotels. The slippers are in the wardrobe and traditional yukata robes in the chest of drawers. If you鈥檙e a fan of baths rather than showers you may find the bath small. As other have mentioned the TV may have plenty of channels but unless you speak Japanese you鈥檒l be restricted in your viewing to CNN and one of the Japanese stations that shows a daily English-language film.However, you鈥檇 need to be crazy to want to sit around watching TV with Asakusa on your doorstep. This is a fascinating low-rise part of Tokyo, criss-crossed by streets packed with small specialist shops and restaurants. You can get to the Senso-ji temple in 5 minutes; all around the temple you鈥檒l find specialists dealing in fabrics, kimonos, fans, umbrellas 鈥?you name it, there鈥檚 probably a shop specialising in it. Further south near the Tawaramachi subway station [Ginza line] you鈥檒l find shops selling religious goods (e.g. Buddhist and Shinto household shrines) and you鈥檙e near the Kappabashi 鈥淜itchen City鈥?as well. The Post Office (where the ATMs accept foreign bank cards) is right beside Tawaramachi subway stationIf you walk 5 minutes further west from Senso-ji you鈥檒l find the Asakusa station [Tobu line] for trains to the opulent historic shrines at Nikko (c. 2 hours). Further south along the riverbank is the Asakusa waterbus terminal for river ferries 鈥?we went to the first stop at the lovely Hama Rikyu gardens but you can continue all the way to the harbour. And the river bus terminal is very near the Asakusa subway station [Asakusa line] where Asakusa-Dori meets the river Sumida. (BTW the multiplicity of stations called 鈥楢sakusa鈥?is confusing 鈥?sadly the one nearest the hotel is the least useful, being almost the end of the Tsukuba suburban rail line; the Asakusa subway station [Ginza line] is not too far from the Kaminari-mon or Thunder Gate of the temple).Back to the hotel: there are 5 restaurants鈥?French and Chinese on the top floors, two Japanese on the 6th floor, and the Caf茅 de Kapiten on the ground floor. We tried the sushi restaurant on the 6th and the de Kapiten on our first and last nights, respectively. Both were fine 鈥?the de Kapiten is less atmospheric and cheaper. I would say however that you will eat as well or better for less outside the hotel. You鈥檙e spoilt for choice 鈥?we enjoyed the Korean (barbecue) 鈥楬on Jin鈥?across the road and the sushi restaurant only yards away on the same side of the road (just go out, turn right and it鈥檚 less than a minute away). Minibar prices are expensive but the hotel shop is not, or for a wider selection of non-alcoholic drinks there鈥檚 a streetside vending machine near the sushi place I mentioned above.My partner is disabled and walks with the help of a stick or 3-wheeler walking aid. The Asakusa View presented no problems whatsoever 鈥?probably the easiest hotel we鈥檝e ever stayed in. And the surrounding area was also a blessing, with many interesting sights only moments from the hotel for those days when we didn鈥檛 feel like being energetic.As a final tip, if arriving with Narita with heavy bags, go to the luggage delivery service counters on the ground floor and for a reasonable price they will take your bags and deliver them to your hotel. We dropped 2 cases off at 11:00 for re-delivery between 16:00 and 20:00 at a cost of c. 拢15 ($30). This made the trip by Keizei train to Ueno station very easy indeed (trains accessible from ground floor of airport); the taxi from Ueno to the hotel cost maybe 拢8 ($16) or you can get the subway 2 stops to Tawaramachi [Ginza line] and walk up Nishiasakusa to the hotel. Returning to the airport you need to send your bags the day before if using the luggage delivery service; the hotel can arrange this.
Reviews.Author: Gebwart

Reviews.Content: Adequate Whilst I would agree that the staff are friendly, I would stress that, in our experience, they are no more so than in rest of Japan. I would therefore consider the reviews below to be misleading.I would consider the hotel to be a little tired/dated - the room we had was a bit '80s. The worst thing about it was the nicotine stained ceiling. It was supposed to be a non-smoking hotel.If you desperately want to stay in Asakusa, this is an ok option. However I wouldn't go out of my way to stay there.
Reviews.Author: Mountebank

Reviews.Content: Concur in past few reviews of Asakusa I agree with the past few reviews about this hotel .The staff were very polite and helpful especially the concierge lady who couldn't do enough for us .The room was clean and comfortable (if a little 1970's in decor) .We only ate breakfast in the hotel which was a buffet with a range of Western and japanese breakfasts .We felt very safe walking around the area and commuted in to the centre of Tokyo by subway.A good supermarket next door where we stocked up on wine for our room ! There is a bar at the top of the hotel which i think is supposed to be for members but the concierge just gave us tickets for it although the drinks were a little on the pricey side .
Reviews.Author: KSlondon

Reviews.Content: Friendliest Staff Ever ! Stayed 4 nights at the Asakusa View Hotel at the beginning of May on my first trip to Tokyo. Having booked through Expedia and benefiting from an excellent price I was expecting a standard 3 star hotel.But as my taxi pulled up I was pleasantly surprised, as I was met by a smart hotel porter and ushered into a gleaming and spotless reception hall. First impressions do count and the welcome and courtesy showed by the porter and reception staff were gratefully welcomed after a long flight from London.Throughout my stay I can not fault any staff member how were so polite and professional throughout, especially the reception manager who was especially helpful. All the staff speak English which was a relief as my Japanese consists of 4 words.Room on the 11th floor, spotless if a little tired but great view out onto the Senso Ji Temple and beyond. Bed very comfortable, bathroom small but manageable with a heated toilet seat and double action bidet. Only gripe was the only English language channel TV in room was the dreadful CNN.Ate once in the hotel at the Cafe de Kapiten which was pleasant, good service but meal nothing special. Lots of good restaurants and bars around on the other side of the road in front of the hotel. Very safe and colourful area. Hotel has a supermarket next door and a few minutes down the street a 7-11, and a Rox department store with basement foodhall. Ideal for stocking up with goodies and could purchase a breakfast consisting of a drink, cake and sandwich all for less of the price of a fruit juice on the hotel menu. Nice cake shop in the hotel lobby, little cafe behind expensive (拢5 for a cup of coffee) other shops in the hotels shopping centre naff. Most guests here at the hotel seem to be Japanese or from mainland Asia, I think I was the only European which was refreshing.Caught the Keisei Skyliner from Narita Airport to Ueno Station on arrival and then a taxi to the hotel (about 拢10) Going back if your not weighed down with luggage then I would recommend the 10 minute walk down to Tawaramachi Station and take the subway to Ueno Station ( about 70p)
Reviews.Author: Durhamguy

Reviews.Content: So much fancier than expected for price Thought we had picked a medium size, medium priced hotel. Walked up to find fancy lobby - doormen - the works. English speaking staff is not as prevalent as you would wish - but that is true throughout Tokyo - surprised us how little English there is. Concierge is helpful to a fault - came to our room loaded down with brochures. Large room with bay window view of temple and the happenings of the neighborhood. No breakfast included. Wireless costs daily extra but not verymuch compared to USA. Fancy lobby with stores - don;t skip the Karoke room downstairs - its not a bar like we think of here - but private sound system rooms with couches and a bartender, snack menu for a private fun night. Subway stop right next door - BE CAREFUL - everyone will try to send you to neighborhhod Asakusa subway stop but you want stop about 1 or two beyond that from town (airport) and you will be at hotel.
Reviews.Author: slce123

Reviews.Content: Affordable, Spacious and Comfortable       View of the hotel from Senso-Ji
Reviews.Author: Bisclimpkit

Reviews.Content: Clean, modern, elegant Asakusa View Hotel We spent two nights in the Asakusa View Hotel. We actually experienced two different rooms at the hotel because we spent one night, left our suitcases at the hotel (which they held for us for no charge), took an overnight excursion to Hakone, and then spent one more night at the Asakusa View.The hotel is a large, modern hotel with several restaurants. The rooms feature beautiful picture windows with great views. Both of the rooms we had were clean and quite spacious (which surprised us as we had heard that hotel rooms in Tokyo are small). Both rooms also had large (king?) beds, desks, sitting areas, vanity areas, and generously-sized bathrooms. We liked one room a bit better as the furnishings were more updated, and it was on the side of the hotel with a view of Senso-ji, so you might want to ask for that if you go.The hotel is conveniently located near transportation, shops, and restaurants. The hotel staff was very friendly, and everyone we dealt with spoke English, so interacting with the staff was easy.We paid about $160/night.
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
